body:
### Describe your issue

Take a very simple extension type:

```
# distutils: extra_compile_args = -DPy_LIMITED_API=0x030C0000

cdef class C:
    pass
```

and in Python (rather than Cython) code, create/destroy it many times:

```
def tst():
    for i in range(20000):
        x = C()
```

It's somewhere around 20% slower in the Limited API than not.

Some notes:
* compiling with `CYTHON_LIMITED_API=0x030C0000` and `Py_LIMITED_API=0x030C0000` are about equal. So I don't think it's because Python functions/macros aren't being inlined.
* compiling with `CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SPECS=1` makes almost no difference so it isn't a heaptype/statictype difference.
* compiling with `CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS=0` accounts for approximately half the difference. I tried a few things to avoid going through `PyType_GetSlot` (e.g.  just calling `PyObject_GenericAlloc` when the type is the expected type) but they didn't seem to make a huge difference.

It may well be that this is unavoidable - I certainly didn't find anything obvious to improve it. But it would be nice if it were quicker.

Cross-reference https://github.com/flintlib/python-flint/pull/349
title: Extension type construction/destruction is slow in the Stable ABI
